trans-unit.source: Retrain Machine Learning models programmatically | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Retrain Machine Learning models programmatically | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to programmatically retrain a model and update the web service to use the newly trained model in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to programmatically retrain a model and update the web service to use the newly trained model in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: Retrain Machine Learning models programmatically
trans-unit.target: Retrain Machine Learning models programmatically

trans-unit.source: As part of the process of operationalization of machine learning models in Azure Machine Learning, a model needs to be trained and saved, then used to create a scoring web service.
trans-unit.target: As part of the process of operationalization of machine learning models in Azure Machine Learning, a model needs to be trained and saved, then used to create a scoring web service.

trans-unit.source: The web service can then be consumed in web sites, dashboards, and mobile apps.
trans-unit.target: The web service can then be consumed in web sites, dashboards, and mobile apps.

trans-unit.source: Frequently, you need to retrain the model created in the first step with new data.
trans-unit.target: Frequently, you need to retrain the model created in the first step with new data.

trans-unit.source: Previously, this was only possible through the Azure ML UI, but with the introduction of the Programmatic Retraining API feature, you now can retrain the model and update the Web Service, to use the newly trained model, programmatically using the Retraining APIs.
trans-unit.target: Previously, this was only possible through the Azure ML UI, but with the introduction of the Programmatic Retraining API feature, you now can retrain the model and update the Web Service, to use the newly trained model, programmatically using the Retraining APIs.

trans-unit.source: This document describes the above process, and shows how to use the Retraining APIs.
trans-unit.target: This document describes the above process, and shows how to use the Retraining APIs.

trans-unit.source: Why retrain: defining the problem
trans-unit.target: Why retrain: defining the problem

trans-unit.source: As part of the ML training process, a model is trained using a set of data.
trans-unit.target: As part of the ML training process, a model is trained using a set of data.

trans-unit.source: The models needs to be retrained in scenarios where new data becomes available, or when the consumer of the API has their own data to train the model, or when the data needs to be filtered and the model trained with the subset of data, etc.
trans-unit.target: The models needs to be retrained in scenarios where new data becomes available, or when the consumer of the API has their own data to train the model, or when the data needs to be filtered and the model trained with the subset of data, etc.

trans-unit.source: In these scenarios, a programmatic API provides a convenient way to allow you or the consumer of your APIs to create a client that can, on a one-time or regular basis, retrain the model using their own data.
trans-unit.target: In these scenarios, a programmatic API provides a convenient way to allow you or the consumer of your APIs to create a client that can, on a one-time or regular basis, retrain the model using their own data.

trans-unit.source: They can then evaluate the results of retraining, and update the Web Service API to use the newly trained model.
trans-unit.target: They can then evaluate the results of retraining, and update the Web Service API to use the newly trained model.

trans-unit.source: How to retrain: the end to end process
trans-unit.target: How to retrain: the end to end process

trans-unit.source: To start, the process involves the following components: a Training Experiment and a Scoring Experiment published as a Web Service.
trans-unit.target: To start, the process involves the following components: a Training Experiment and a Scoring Experiment published as a Web Service.

trans-unit.source: To enable retraining of a trained model, the Training Experiment has to also be published as a Web Service with the output of a trained model.
trans-unit.target: To enable retraining of a trained model, the Training Experiment has to also be published as a Web Service with the output of a trained model.

trans-unit.source: This enables API access to the model for retraining.
trans-unit.target: This enables API access to the model for retraining.

trans-unit.source: The process for setting up retraining involves the following steps:
trans-unit.target: The process for setting up retraining involves the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Diagram 1: Retraining process overview
trans-unit.target: Diagram 1: Retraining process overview

trans-unit.source: *Create a Training Experiment*
trans-unit.target: *Create a Training Experiment*

trans-unit.source: We will be using experiment “Sample 5 (Train, Test, Evaluate for Binary Classification: Adult Dataset)” from the Azure ML sample experiments for this example.
trans-unit.target: We will be using experiment “Sample 5 (Train, Test, Evaluate for Binary Classification: Adult Dataset)” from the Azure ML sample experiments for this example.

trans-unit.source: As you will see below, I have simplified the sample by removing some modules.
trans-unit.target: As you will see below, I have simplified the sample by removing some modules.

trans-unit.source: I have also named the experiment “Census Model”.
trans-unit.target: I have also named the experiment “Census Model”.

trans-unit.source: With these pieces in place, we can now click Run on the bottom of the screen to run this experiment.
trans-unit.target: With these pieces in place, we can now click Run on the bottom of the screen to run this experiment.

trans-unit.source: Create a Scoring Experiment and publish as a Web Service
trans-unit.target: Create a Scoring Experiment and publish as a Web Service

trans-unit.source: After experiment run is completed, we click on Create Scoring Experiment.
trans-unit.target: After experiment run is completed, we click on Create Scoring Experiment.

trans-unit.source: This creates a Scoring Experiment, saves the model as a Trained Model and adds Web Service Input and Output modules as shown below.
trans-unit.target: This creates a Scoring Experiment, saves the model as a Trained Model and adds Web Service Input and Output modules as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Next, we click Run.
trans-unit.target: Next, we click Run.

trans-unit.source: After experiment run is completed, clicking on “Publish Web Service” will publish the Scoring Experiment as a Web Service and create a default endpoint.
trans-unit.target: After experiment run is completed, clicking on “Publish Web Service” will publish the Scoring Experiment as a Web Service and create a default endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The trained model in this webservice is updatable, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: The trained model in this webservice is updatable, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: The details for this endpoint will then show up on the screen.
trans-unit.target: The details for this endpoint will then show up on the screen.

trans-unit.source: *Publish the Training Experiment as a Web Service*
trans-unit.target: *Publish the Training Experiment as a Web Service*

trans-unit.source: To re-train the trained model, we need to publish the Training Experiment we created in step 1 above as a Web Service.
trans-unit.target: To re-train the trained model, we need to publish the Training Experiment we created in step 1 above as a Web Service.

trans-unit.source: This Web Service will need a Web Service Output module connected to the [Train Model][train-model] module, to be able to produce new trained models.
trans-unit.target: This Web Service will need a Web Service Output module connected to the [Train Model][train-model] module, to be able to produce new trained models.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Experiments icon in the left pane, then click on the experiment called Census Model to go back to the training experiment.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Experiments icon in the left pane, then click on the experiment called Census Model to go back to the training experiment.

trans-unit.source: We then add one Web Service Input and two Web Service Output modules to the workflow.
trans-unit.target: We then add one Web Service Input and two Web Service Output modules to the workflow.

trans-unit.source: The Web Service output for Train Model will give us the new trained model.
trans-unit.target: The Web Service output for Train Model will give us the new trained model.

trans-unit.source: The output attached to Evaluate Model will return that module’s Evaluate Model output.
trans-unit.target: The output attached to Evaluate Model will return that module’s Evaluate Model output.

trans-unit.source: We can now click Run.
trans-unit.target: We can now click Run.

trans-unit.source: After experiment has completed running, the resulting workflow should look as below:
trans-unit.target: After experiment has completed running, the resulting workflow should look as below:

trans-unit.source: We next click on the Publish Web Service button, then click Yes.
trans-unit.target: We next click on the Publish Web Service button, then click Yes.

trans-unit.source: This will publish the Training Experiment as a Web Service that produces a trained model and model evaluation results.
trans-unit.target: This will publish the Training Experiment as a Web Service that produces a trained model and model evaluation results.

trans-unit.source: The Web Service Dashboard will be displayed with the API Key and the API help page for Batch Execution.
trans-unit.target: The Web Service Dashboard will be displayed with the API Key and the API help page for Batch Execution.

trans-unit.source: Note that only the Batch Execution method can be used for creating Trained Models.
trans-unit.target: Note that only the Batch Execution method can be used for creating Trained Models.

trans-unit.source: *Add a new Endpoint*
trans-unit.target: *Add a new Endpoint*

trans-unit.source: The Scoring Web Service we published in Step 2 above was created with a default endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The Scoring Web Service we published in Step 2 above was created with a default endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The default endpoints are kept in sync with the original training and scoring experiments, and therefore a default endpoint's trained model cannot be replaced.
trans-unit.target: The default endpoints are kept in sync with the original training and scoring experiments, and therefore a default endpoint's trained model cannot be replaced.

trans-unit.source: To create an updatable endpoint visit the Azure Portal and click on Add Endpoint (more details [here](machine-learning-create-endpoint.md)).
trans-unit.target: To create an updatable endpoint visit the Azure Portal and click on Add Endpoint (more details [here](machine-learning-create-endpoint.md)).

trans-unit.source: *Retrain the model with new data and BES*
trans-unit.target: *Retrain the model with new data and BES*

trans-unit.source: To call the Retraining APIs, we create a new C# Console Application in Visual Studio (New->Project->Windows Desktop->Console Application).
trans-unit.target: To call the Retraining APIs, we create a new C# Console Application in Visual Studio (New->Project->Windows Desktop->Console Application).

trans-unit.source: We then copy the sample C# code from the Training Web Service's API help page for batch execution (created in Step 3 above) and paste it into the Program.cs file, making sure the namespace remains intact.
trans-unit.target: We then copy the sample C# code from the Training Web Service's API help page for batch execution (created in Step 3 above) and paste it into the Program.cs file, making sure the namespace remains intact.

trans-unit.source: Note that sample code has comments which indicate parts of the code that need updates.
trans-unit.target: Note that sample code has comments which indicate parts of the code that need updates.

trans-unit.source: Also, when specifiying the "output1" location in the Reqeust Payload, the file extention of the "RelativeLocation" has to be changed an ".ileaner" as in "Outputs": {Global Parameters ... { "output1": { "ConnectionString": "DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=mystorageacct;AccountKey=Dx9WbMIThAvXRQWap/aLnxT9LV5txxw==", "RelativeLocation": "mycontainer/output1results.ilearner"}}.
trans-unit.target: Also, when specifiying the "output1" location in the Reqeust Payload, the file extention of the "RelativeLocation" has to be changed an ".ileaner" as in "Outputs": {Global Parameters ... { "output1": { "ConnectionString": "DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=mystorageacct;AccountKey=Dx9WbMIThAvXRQWap/aLnxT9LV5txxw==", "RelativeLocation": "mycontainer/output1results.ilearner"}}.

trans-unit.source: Provide Azure Storage info
trans-unit.target: Provide Azure Storage info

trans-unit.source: The sample code for BES will upload a file from a local drive (e.g. “C:\temp\CensusIpnput.csv”) to Azure Storage, process it, and write the results back to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The sample code for BES will upload a file from a local drive (e.g. “C:\temp\CensusIpnput.csv”) to Azure Storage, process it, and write the results back to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: To accomplish that, you need to retrieve the Storage account name, key, and container information from the Azure Management Portal for your Storage account and the update the code here.
trans-unit.target: To accomplish that, you need to retrieve the Storage account name, key, and container information from the Azure Management Portal for your Storage account and the update the code here.

trans-unit.source: You also need to ensure the input file is available at the location you specify in the code.
trans-unit.target: You also need to ensure the input file is available at the location you specify in the code.

trans-unit.source: We had set up this Training Experiment with two outputs, so the results will include storage location information for both of them, as seen below.
trans-unit.target: We had set up this Training Experiment with two outputs, so the results will include storage location information for both of them, as seen below.

trans-unit.source: “output1” is the output of the Trained Model, “output2” the output of Evaluate Model.
trans-unit.target: “output1” is the output of the Trained Model, “output2” the output of Evaluate Model.

trans-unit.source: Also note that the file extention of the Output for the Trained Model (Output1) is ".ileaner" and not ".csv".
trans-unit.target: Also note that the file extention of the Output for the Trained Model (Output1) is ".ileaner" and not ".csv".

trans-unit.source: *Evaluate the Retraining Results*
trans-unit.target: *Evaluate the Retraining Results*

trans-unit.source: Using the combination of the BaseLocation, RelativeLocaiton and SasBlobToken from the above output results for “output2” we can see the performance results of the retrained model by pasting the complete URL in the browser address bar.
trans-unit.target: Using the combination of the BaseLocation, RelativeLocaiton and SasBlobToken from the above output results for “output2” we can see the performance results of the retrained model by pasting the complete URL in the browser address bar.

trans-unit.source: This will tell us if the newly trained model performs well enough to replace the existing one.
trans-unit.target: This will tell us if the newly trained model performs well enough to replace the existing one.

trans-unit.source: *Update the added endpoint’s Trained Model*
trans-unit.target: *Update the added endpoint’s Trained Model*

trans-unit.source: To complete the process, we need to update the trained model of the scoring endpoint we created in Step 4 above.
trans-unit.target: To complete the process, we need to update the trained model of the scoring endpoint we created in Step 4 above.

trans-unit.source: The BES output above shows the information for the result of retraining for “output1” which contains the retrained model location information.
trans-unit.target: The BES output above shows the information for the result of retraining for “output1” which contains the retrained model location information.

trans-unit.source: We now need to take this trained model and update the scoring endpoint.
trans-unit.target: We now need to take this trained model and update the scoring endpoint.

trans-unit.source: (created in step 4 above)
trans-unit.target: (created in step 4 above)

trans-unit.source: The “apiKey” and the “endpointUrl” for this call are visible on the endpoint dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The “apiKey” and the “endpointUrl” for this call are visible on the endpoint dashboard.

trans-unit.source: With the success of this call, the new endpoint will start using a retrained model approximately within 15 seconds.
trans-unit.target: With the success of this call, the new endpoint will start using a retrained model approximately within 15 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: Using the Retraining APIs, we can update the trained model of a predictive Web Service enabling scenarios such as periodic model retraining with new data or distribution of models to customers with the goal of letting them retrain the model using their own data.
trans-unit.target: Using the Retraining APIs, we can update the trained model of a predictive Web Service enabling scenarios such as periodic model retraining with new data or distribution of models to customers with the goal of letting them retrain the model using their own data.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
